ygData.subject: Re: New Paper: Ontogeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms

Hi Jeff, congrats on another very interesting and thought-provoking paper=
.  I agree with some of your points from your post but I also wanted to men=
tion a couple where I differ.  

I agree strongly with your conclusion that=
 simply because phenotypic diversity is a good thing does not mean that gen=
otypic diversity should be discarded.  They play different and complementar=
y roles.  I'm glad to hear you drew that conclusion from this work.

Where =
I somewhat differ is on the "bolting on" issue.  You mentioned that I have =
pointed out that in target-based search evolution "never takes the time to =
redesign from the ground up" and keeps "hacking in/bolting on new things th=
at happen to work."  However, I would like to make a distinction between yo=
ur characterization and my view.  First, my view is that *all* evolution "n=
ever takes the time to redesign from the ground up" and keeps "hacking in/b=
olting on new things that happen to work," both in non-objective and object=
ive-based evolution.  Those are ubiquitous qualities of evolution regardles=
s of how it's rewarded:  Its mutations are inherently ad hoc and it is virt=
ually impossible to "redesign" an ad hoc construction in the middle of a se=
arch.  That's true in nature, in Picbreeder, in objective-based algorithms,=
 and probably true in Avida (though I'm not experienced in Avida).

Second,=
 in my view the key distinction between non-objective and objective search =
is that objective search tends to produce representations that are *piecewi=
se*.  In other words, while both non-object and objective search proceed in=
 an ad-hoc "bolting on" manner, the bolted-on components in the objective s=
earch tend to be irregular additions that slightly raise fitness at the exp=
ense of ruining the representation for future generations.  That is because=
 in objective search there is no reward for establishing any regularities. =
 In non-objective search, on the other hand, often a regularity is preserve=
d because it offers something fundamentally new (i.e. neither good nor bad)=
 and then later becomes the basis for endless elaboration (like bilateral s=
ymmetry).  You can't establish something like symmetry early in an objectiv=
e search because symmetry on its own looks nothing like the final objective=
, even if theoretically it would be helpful in principle in finding it.  

=
I'm also not sure whether it's really accurate to say Avida is "not target-=
based."  It's true that it's not as explicit as a single simple objective f=
unction, but the fact that there are several logical operations that explic=
itly give an advantage to organisms that execute them actually does create =
a form of objective-driven pressure.  In other words, the creativity of evo=
lution in Avida with such a priori human-defined rewards is to some extent =
hampered by the need to stay competitive on those arbitrary objectives.  So=
 I'd expect it to be closer to objective search (when used in that mode) th=
an non-objective search, though somewhere on the continuum between them.  I=
 also understand that Avida as a platform doesn't have to be run with those=
 rewards, but if I understand correctly they are traditional and used in th=
is particular paper as well.

However, I think these differences in perspec=
tive don't really detract from the main point of the paper regarding ontoge=
ny and phylogeny.  But I mention them mainly as a side-conversation on obje=
ctive vs. non-objective search and their effects.

ken


--- In neat@yahoog=
roups.com, Jeff Clune <jeffclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all,
> 
> I wanted t=
o let you know about a new paper I recently published. I did not use NEAT, =
but there are messages in the paper that relate to some of the conversation=
s we've had on this list.
> 
> Clune J, Pennock RT, Ofria C, Lenski RE
> On=
togeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms. 
> The America=
n Naturalist.  2012. 180: E54=96E63.
> PDF: http://jeffclune.com/publicatio=
ns/2012-CluneEtAl-OntegenyRecapitulatesPhylogeny-AmNat.pdf
> Popular press =
writeup of the paper: http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/08/12081013=
3155.htm
> 
> The first relevant subject regards evolving good representati=
ons. The work of Joel, Ken, and colleagues has shown some interesting thing=
s regarding when we can expect bad representations, such as in target-based=
 search, where evolution keeps hacking in/bolting on new things that happen=
 to work, and never takes the time to redesign from the ground up (or even =
at middle levels). Nature, however, does something similar (though perhaps =
to a much lesser degree): vestigial organs and developmental stages hang ar=
ound, including intermediate developmental forms that are built and then di=
ssolve entirely. In this paper we looked into whether we could see evidence=
 of that "bolting on" in Avida, a digital evolution platform that is not ta=
rget-based in that it does not have an explicit fitness function. We found =
evidence for bolting on, just as we would expect from the existence of vest=
igial developmental stages in biological organisms: new functionality tende=
d to appear later in the development of an organism, because mutations that=
 changed things more fundamentally/deeper in the representation were more l=
ikely to be deleterious and were more quickly weeded out by selection. I th=
ink the lesson is that this bolting on process is largely inevitable, thoug=
h I think it is a fascinating question whether it is less of an issue in di=
vergent search vs. convergent search. 
> 
> A second issue related to this =
list is that, because evolution tends to quickly select away mutations that=
 deeply change representations, it is likely a good idea to have something =
like the genomic diversity protection in NEAT. Because recent work has show=
n that phenotypic/behavioral diversity is more effective than genotypic div=
ersity, many people may be switching to phenotypic diversity and abandoning=
 genomic diversity: this work suggests that both may be important. For exam=
ple, mutations that affect a representation deeply may initially hurt the o=
rganism's ability to do something behaviorally different/interesting, for t=
he same reason that such mutations hurts fitness (e.g. they cripple the org=
anism). Protecting that innovation for a while may thus pay off.  In other =
words, because selection will quickly work to eliminate deep changes, we sh=
ould probably protect them for a while if we want to see better representat=
ions emerge.  
> 
> In the paper, we focus on an interesting consequence of=
 bolting on: if new functionality is added to the end of an organism's life=
, then the order that an organism develops will tend to contain information=
 about the order that traits evolved in its lineage, and vice-versa. That h=
elps settle an age old debate by showing that "ontogeny tends to recapitula=
te phylogeny". 
> 
> Please let me know if you have any questions or commen=
ts. 
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Visiting Scientist
> Cornell Univ=
ersity
> jeffclune@...
> jeffclune.com
>
